comment.author: 76016463@N00
comment._content: This is no doubt connected to the meeting of a group of Hungarian American citizens, with President Wilson at the White House on February 23, 1916, under the leadership of Alexander Konta (photo, front center). They were to present him with a petition swearing loyalty to the U.S., signed by several thousand American citizens born in Hungary. select.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=F60B17F93E5E1373... The Times listed those who planned to attend: Alexander Konta Rev. John Froelich, St. Stephens Roman Catholic Church of New York, Rev. Stephen F. Chernitzky, Bridgeport, Connecticut Rev. Lajos de Kovacs, Youngstown, Ohio Rev. Dr. Zoltan Kuthy, Pastor, First Magyar Reformed Church, Julius Volgyi, "secretary of a society of more than 14,000 members" Dr. Frank I. Horn, Chief Surgeon at St. Mark's Hospital, Dr. Morris Cukor, attorney, Geza D. Berko, owner of the Hungarian daily newspaper Nepszava Geza Kende, editorial writer Josef Haan, St. Regis Hotel The pictured group is mostly the same, assuming Y.D. Kende is Geza Kende. The four women are likely the wives of Haan, Berko, Cukor and Horn. Missing from the Times group is Rev. Dr. Zoltan Kuthy. Pictured, but not in the Times description, are Rev. Harsanyi and Rev. Szabo. An account of what transpired at the meeting with Wilson: query.nytimes.com/gst/abstract.html?res=9A05E2D9103FE233A... More on Alexander Konta under A biographical sketch of Morris Cukor: www.sk-szeged.hu/statikus_html/vasvary/newsletter/10dec/m...
